comment: Kinda boring, probably cheap enough for a third drink whiskey...
Very flavorful, not the smoothest I've ever had

Nose: Tangy yet smooth, malty and floral fragrant with honey.

Taste: Malt with wee spices and wood.

Finish: Very smooth overall but with some tangy notes.

Balance: Good idea but something falls short in execution. Sheep Dip is too flat without personality.
Very smooth. Lacks the bite I really crave. Other than that a decent scotch whiskey.
Very drinkable. No nose tickle. Smoother than expected, but finishes kind of weakly.
Not sweet...a bit smoky. Nothing special
strong nose, very smooth. No lines on the glass.
Very light, but hangs around for awhile.  Very enjoyable.
Does have a sweet hint at first but mostly boozy, tastes rich. Leaves an unpleasant aftertaste.
Kinda like a girl you've dated before.  Nose has hints of floral notes and fruits.  Very smooth from taste to finish but got kinda of boring real quick...

Surprisingly enjoyable for the price...
C: honey
N: VERY pronounced dark chocolate covered cherry
P: Bittersweet chocolate and toffee
F: Pleasantly extended sweet caramel.

Then, after adding 5 drops of water-
N: Praline pecans and toffee
P: Butterscotch
F: Cream and artificial sweetener
Very smooth, nothing special,  wood grainy, with a touch of floral mixed with caramel nose

Don't let the rather pungent nose throw you, this is a fairly smooth scotch, with hints of spice, wood, and the sea on the palate. It finishes smooth, but relatively quickly too. Not great, but not actively bad either. What would be 3/5 becomes 2/5 due to the price - it's just not worth that much, IMO.
It's nothing to go crazy over. Much better whiskey for price
Aged in American oak barrels, Sheep Dip is a smooth blended whiskey. Not too peaty. Rich flavor. Medium sweetness.

Decent, but not worth the $40. More to be had from Compass Box for the money, otherwise either spend a little more or stick to a good bourbon. Strong apple aroma, but doesn't come through on the palate. Simple but not offensive.

[9/6/17] Out here on the company dollar again, figured the risk is pretty minimal. The name drew me in but I probably won't own a bottle. Ever. 

Mild, with no distinction. Sure, its creamy, smooth finishing and soft toffee. The char has a hint of vanilla reminiscent of scratch cask scotch. But this is neither memorable nor a value buy.
For me a high two... floral (Soapy?) on the nose. Initial taste is sweet, but doesn't last very long and becomes rather bitter.
great entry sipper, great price point

Nose is a little fruity, sweet.
Taste is: Vanilla, honey, Salt, smoke, earthy

Pretty good, but I don’t know if I’d buy again.
Good value for the $. Somewhat antiseptic tasting to me. Little bit of smoke and peat. Did not like it neat... new or even after half the bottle was gone. Really was a lot better with an ice cube.

82 is harsh, man. Real harsh. This is surprisingly good.

It's sweet, with honey and malted barley on the nose. There are also touches of vanilla and fruit on the palate. Body is good, and finish is light and delicate with hints of walnut. 

Give it a try.
this is the best intro to peet for a new wiskey drinker i have found to date!
Good intro Islay. Peatheads will want more though.
Nose and palate remind me of tequila. Not a fan of this blend.
to light in taste and a heavily alcoholic finish to me
Rather good blend. Very up front on the palate with toasted cereal and toffee candy. Smooth finish.
A vanilla or toffee aroma.   Harsher than Jameson’s.   Reminded of Auchentoshan
Very nice blend. Smooth with a touch of peat on the finish

Tasting in a small snifter.

Color: Mellow gold

Nose: Stewed apple, cinnamon, red grape skin, faint smoke.

Pallet: campfire ash, stewed fruit, cherry, oak, cinnamon, nutmeg

Finish: Light smoke, oak spice, medium length finish.

This is a gem for those who want something with a smoked fruity nose and pallet this is worth picking up.

Nose: Wafts of generic fruit, oak, cereal, etc. but it's not very impressive and is remarkably like the nose of a blended scotch.

Palate: The arrival is spicy and sweetish, veering towards heat as it rests in the mouth, and then suddenly blooming with sour harsh malt and bitter coffee. The texture is not noteworthy.

Finish: Short. Fleeting malty notes from the late palate compete with sour grains in the aftertaste.

If you encounter this as part of a blind tasting I guarantee you'll guess it to be a bottom shelf blended scotch.  There is a thin hardness to both the nose and palate and an unwelcome ethanol stain. It is certainly the least characterful or engaging blended malt I've tasted. I'd put it on the same level as Johnnie Walker Red Label (to which it bears something of a resemblance).

Even a small dash of water kills the nose but it does, mercifully, soften the palate a little. It's definitely at its best as a mixer with soft drinks, where (just like blended scotch) the hard finish is balanced by the sweetness of cola, lemonade, ginger ale or what have you. My first inclination was to give this 1.5 stars but I'm raising that to 1.75 based on it's performance as a mixer. However it is neither good value nor worth the official rating of 82. I won't be buying another bottle.

(PS - I have a strong suspicion that this is an opportunistic blend and the formula has some elasticity).

"Adequate" : 1.75 stars
I’m warming up to it, but I was not at all happy with it the first, second or even third time
Not bad. I pick up more of the Islay profile than anything else but seems decently balanced.
Decent blend. No complaints but at the price ($38) I personally prefer Monkey Shoulder. Glad I gave it a try but probably will not buy again.

This is very similar to their blended scotch Pigs nose which is decent. This is better........Poured neat , nose is bready malt, some light apple cinnamon and tea leaves with a bit of barrel and char. Palate is more of the same with sweet malt, oaky dough and char. Maybe a wisp of smoke but more like the fire's been out a long time. Finish is drying malt and char with wood notes that linger. Overall I find it pretty enjoyable. Vatted malt so no grain harshness to deal with. However its a little pricey(for malt blend) at mid to high 30's. Deanston virgin oak is in this profile, tastes better imo and is less$. Still Im not disappointed with Sheep Dip and even give it a recommend score of 83/100...........If you find it for decent price worth a shot if you like malty "scotchy" scotch
By far the best blended at this price point.
Best of the Blended Single Malts I’ve had so far.  Do not let cabinet run out.
